oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps crew working in Pickett State Forest
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of four men raking a forest floor. All are wearing hats. The photo is pasted on loose-leaf paper.

Formed in March 1933, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was among the first of Franklin D. Roosevelt's alphabet agencies designed to ease the effects of the Depression. The relief agency promoted environmental conservation and intended to build good citizens through vigorous, disciplined outdoor labor. The CCC built roads, hiking trails, state parks and forests, fire towers, bridges, and other public works. Soil conservation and reforestation were CCC signatures. The �Tree Army� relieved rural unemployment and keep youth out of trouble.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Watson, C.
